snippet: Investors seeking smart advice should be mindful of what a financial adviser is not disclosing to them.
abstract: Tara Siegel Bernard Your Money column advises investors to be wary of bank and brokerage firm employees, saying their titles do not always truly reflect their qualifications; notes that some employees are salesman rather than true investment advisers, and that many are not required by law to disclose conflicts of interest that may compromise their advice.
lead_paragraph: Investors seeking smart advice should be mindful of what a financial adviser is not disclosing to them.

headline.seo: Beware of Fancy Financial Adviser Titles
headline.main: A Fancy Financial Adviser Title Does Not Ensure High Standards
headline.print_headline: A Fancy Financial Adviser Title Does Not Ensure High Standards

keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
